answers.text:
Hi Chantal.  The City of Harrisonburg is currently going through a redesign.  While we are not using a consulting firm, we are seeking citizen input on usability and ultimately format.  
We had a very short survey on our website and also invited members of the community to come in and try to complete some simple tasks on the website.  They then gave us feedback on how usable and intuitive it was.  We also had a very informal conversation about what they would like to see on the site.  The survey is on our website still at www.harrisonburgva.gov if you are interested in seeing it.
We are now at the point where we have drawn up a "road map" of how we would like the site to function and our webmaster is moving forward with design and restructuring.  Once she is done with that, we will have a beta testing group that functions similarly to the testing group we brought in to see if we hit our marks.  We anticipate doing a number of these at different stages.
Staff went through a similar analysis and feedback process before we moved into citizen groups, which was also very helpful.
Let me know if you have questions or would like more information.

We are also coordinating with our local newspaper to announce/make available access to our survey (using Survey Monkey). The questions focus on usability and content satisfaction.

author: Chantal Cotton
text:
Hello everyone,
Has anyone done website redesign through a consultant company (i.e. - Civic Plus) and involved constant community input in the process?  If so, how did you do it?  Did you have the consultant set up the process or did you set it up on your own?
Thanks!
title: Citizen Engagement / Participation in the Website Redesign Process
